raw_text:
Could rivalry overshadow election?
 
 Tony Blair and Gordon Brown are desperately trying to stuff the genie of their rivalry back into the bottle.
 
 Along with any number of senior cabinet colleagues, they are insisting their only job is to win the next election and govern in the best interests of Britain. It is a message they are aiming directly at their backbenchers who are becoming irritated and even unnerved by the continuing claims and counter claims surrounding this alleged rift. Ian Gibson, for example, urged the two men to stop squabbling, declaring: "For goodness sake, sometimes you have to rise above petulance and make sure that you do your job as effectively as you can." Those with slim majorities are particularly fearful that the rift could hit their own hopes of re-election. Tony Blair will seek to reassure Labour MPs on Monday evening at their first meeting of the new year at Westminster - a behind-closed doors meeting which Gordon Brown is thought likely to also attend to show unity.
 
 Meanwhile the likes of Health Secretary John Reid and Labour peer Lord Haskins are warning of the electoral dangers of allowing this soap opera to continue. And they have both warned the rival camps to stop spreading the poison. Lord Haskins even suggested Mr Blair should reinstate Mr Brown as the central figure in the election planning.
 
 But this particular genie is unusually reluctant to return to captivity and many fear it is simply too late to repair the damage. They believe they will be fighting the next election with the sounds of open warfare between the two men ringing in their ears. And it matters little whether the rift is real or, as some try to suggest, simply the product of newspaper headlines and Westminster gossip. Few in Westminster actually believe that, simply because the evidence appears to contradict it.
 
 For example, the weekend's attempts by both men to play down the divisions failed to do the trick. Even as they were both insisting on their unity of purpose and claiming they would not be swayed by newspaper stories, they still managed to stir the speculation with their comments.
 
 Mr Blair talked about the "New" Labour manifesto - a move which seemed calculated to irritate the chancellor, who has long rejected the label. And Mr Brown pointedly refused to deny claims the prime minister had reneged on a deal to hand him the premiership last year. That claim was repeated in Robert Peston's book, a book which amply demonstrates this corrosive Downing Street soap opera is nowhere near its final act.
 
 For his part, Mr Brown insists his only motivation was to get Labour re-elected.
 
 The trouble is, both men have fallen short of offering simple, straightforward denials of the central claims. So they have both been accused of actually making matters worse by feeding the speculation with their own behaviour. The first thing to be said is that these suggestions have not come from nowhere. They started with and are sustained by "friends" of the two men. One only had to listen to the chancellor's friend and former spin chief Charlie Whelan last week to understand that there is a real anger from this camp at the prime minister's apparent attempts to confound Mr Brown's leadership ambitions. But it is not just public pronouncements from ex-aides.
 
 There are whispered briefings to selected journalists from both sides. It is no secret in Westminster, for example, that Downing Street believes the chancellor is indulging in a mammoth sulk and acting in a petty and deliberately provocative manner.
 
 Then there are the actions of the men themselves. Gordon Brown sets out what is seen as a rival manifesto then appears to embark on his own personal campaign. The prime minister responds by scheduling his monthly press conference to clash with a keynote speech by the chancellor. Meanwhile large numbers of backbench MPs insist voters are either entirely uninterested in the chatter, which they believe is a media-only obsession, or that they fear for the efficient running of a government beset by such rivalry. Either way, there is universal agreement that if this goes on through the general election it can only do the Labour party serious damage. There are signs that the two men appreciate the dangers and both want to put a lid on all the speculation. But with probably only four months to the next election, that looks like being a particularly difficult trick to pull off.
llama3.2:1b:
Tony Blair and Gordon Brown are trying to prevent their rivalry from overshadowing the upcoming election by focusing solely on winning and governing for Britain.

Their senior cabinet colleagues are concerned about the impact of their continued claims and counterclaims on backbenchers who may lose hope of re-election if they don't take action.

Ian Gibson has warned that "petulance" is being displayed, and that Labour MPs need to rise above it and do their job effectively.

Health Secretary John Reid and peer Lord Haskins have expressed concerns about the electoral dangers of allowing this rivalry to continue.

Many believe that the rival camps should stop spreading the poison, as many in Westminster think it's just media hype.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown are trying to downplay their rivalry ahead of the next election. Despite claims of a rift between them, they want to focus on winning the election and governing in Britain's best interests. However, some senior cabinet colleagues and Labour MPs are warning that this ongoing speculation could harm their chances in the polls. The rift is seen as too deep-seated for its genie to be easily stuffed back into the bottle.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown are attempting to downplay their ongoing rivalry, but it persists, potentially harming their chances at re-election.  Despite public statements of unity and efforts to suppress speculation, both men's actions and those of their "friends" fuel public perception of the rivalry's impact on their campaigns. Both sides engage in strategic maneuvering that further amplifies the divide, with backbenchers expressing concerns about its effect on policy and efficiency.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's rivalry over government appointments is overshadowed by the current controversy surrounding a scandal involving Health Secretary John Reid and Labour peer Lord Haskins. While both men are working hard to avoid making any accusations, they are concerned that their divisions could spark an election-related scandal. The rift has made it difficult for either man to win re-election in 2017, which is putting pressure on them to prove their leadership abilities once again.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown struggle to maintain unity ahead of their impending general election. While attempting to distance themselves from past rivalries, they find that accusations continue to spread, leading some to fear damaging divisions could impact electoral prospects. Despite efforts by both men to downplay the feud, speculation remains rampant, with some MPs concerned it will distract voters and threaten the party's performance.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown continue their rivalry despite efforts by some to downplay it. They insist they are focused solely on winning the upcoming election. This has led to concerns from Labour backbenchers and cabinet members who fear it could impact their chances of re-election. Despite public denials, both leaders have fueled speculation with their actions, leading to accusations of worsening the situation. Westminster insiders view this as a significant electoral threat for Labour, especially as they prepare for a crucial four-month period before the election.
opencoder:1.5b:
It's important to note that while it may seem concise, the text provided in the question is quite extensive, making it difficult for me to condense or summarize its entirety in this concise format without losing crucial points. However, I can still discuss some of the key points:

1. The two men are facing a rift in their opinion and a potential conflict over which candidate they will choose.
2. They are aiming to reconcile their arguments and move forward in a way that aligns with the interests of their constituents.
3. They believe it would be better for them to focus on the future of the election, rather than trying to create an impasse between rival candidates.
4. The men want to secure a fair and democratic outcome for the British people, while simultaneously aiming for a more united country.
5. Despite the evidence being contradictory, they remain hopeful that this rift will be over in the next election.
6. The first thing they are trying to achieve is not just to get a reelection but also to ensure their allies' prosperity and safety.
7. They believe it would be better for them to play down the divisions that have been faced and to focus on overcoming any possible negative implications that come with similar scenarios in the future.
smollm:1.7b:
The rivalry between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown is indeed a soap opera in its own right, with each man trying to outdo the other in terms of their political prowess and personal brand. The two men have been at odds for years, with each one accusing the other of being overly focused on the Labour Party's internal struggles rather than the wider political landscape.

The key issue is that both men are desperate to win the next election, which they believe will be crucial in determining their own and the country's future. However, there are also reports that both men have been involved in a bitter personal rivalry, with each one accusing the other of being overly focused on their own political ambitions rather than genuinely working together for the benefit of the country.

The key point is that both men believe they will be fighting the next election with the sounds of open warfare between them ringing in their ears. And it matters little whether the rift is real or, as some try to suggest, simply the product of newspaper headlines and Westminster gossip. Few in Westminster actually believe that, simply because the evidence appears to contradict it.

The trouble is, both men have fallen short of offering simple, straightforward denials of the central claims made by their opponents. Instead, they have both been accused of indulging in a mammoth sulk and acting in a petty and deliberately provocative manner. This has led to whispers that there may be more at play than just political differences between the two men.

There are also whispered briefings to selected journalists from both sides, which adds to the sense of tension and speculation surrounding the rivalry. It is no secret in Westminster, for example, that Downing Street believes the chancellor is indulging in a massive sulk and acting in a petty and deliberately provocative manner. The prime minister responds by scheduling his monthly press conference to clash with a keynote speech by the chancellor.

Meanwhile, large numbers of backbench MPs insist voters are either entirely uninterested in the chatter between Blair and Brown or that they fear for the efficient running of a government beset on all sides by political rivalry. Either way, there is universal agreement that if this goes on through the general election it can only do the Labour party serious damage.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text. Let me read through it carefully.

The main points are about Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's rivalry during the 2010 election campaign. They seem to be pushing everything under the radar to avoid getting re-elected. The backbenchers are upset because their rivals keep bringing in more drama. There are warnings from figures like Ian Gibson, John Reid, and Lord Haskins about how this might hurt Labour's chances.

The summary should include key ideas: rivalry overshadowing election, both trying to win without controversy, backbenchers' frustration, warnings from others, and the fear of damage to the party. I'll make sure to keep it concise.
</think>

Rivalry overshadowed the election campaign between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, pushing everything under the radar to avoid re-election. Their rivals were criticized for squabbling over the race, worried that their efforts would hurt Labour's chances. Backbenchers were upset by constant drama, while experts warned of electoral dangers from speculation. They aim to unite during a behind-closed-door meeting to reassure MPs and face a difficult task with only four months left.
tinyllama:1.1b: The article summarizes the main ideas of the text, focusing mainly on the rivalry between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, which has been contributing to political uncertainty in Westminster. The text highlights that there is growing speculation about the details of their alleged feud and the consequences it could have on the upcoming election. Additionally, several key individuals in the British government, including Lord Haskins and John Reid, warn against further escalation of the rivalry while others remain unconvinced. Despite claims that the two men are trying to "rise above petty squabbling," speculation persists, with the public and politicians alike expressing concerns about the possible consequences of the election. Overall, the article suggests that the rivalry is likely to pose a significant threat to the upcoming polls, leading to an uncertain outcome for both men and their supporters.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The rivalry between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown has been simmering for a while now. This election season, however, it's exploded into open conflict. The two leaders are both insisting their relationship is strictly business as they prepare for the next general election. They've been locked in a bitter feud for years over who will lead Britain, but this time they're going to let their egos take center stage.

During Monday's first meeting of the new year, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown are scheduled to discuss how to best manage their political rivalry before the next election. However, their rivalry is not just a matter of policy differences or party loyalty - it's also a public relations nightmare for both leaders. As politicians continue to make claims about the extent of the rivalry and the chances of it impacting the outcome of the general election, their supporters have grown increasingly frustrated with the situation.

But it seems as if Tony Blair is the one who's finally decided they should end the feud once and for all. In a surprising move, he's made an unexpected announcement at his press conference - he's revoking the prime minister's seat on the Labour front bench. This is a clear signal that there will be no more public confrontations or attempts to outmaneuver each other in the coming election season.

Douglas, a loyalist for Tony Blair, believes the decision is a pragmatic one that would help restore some semblance of balance and unity in the Labour party. He thinks it's best if both leaders focus on their core issues and try to move forward without any more drama or rivalry. But for Gordon Brown, who has been accused of using the media as his own personal playground, this decision is likely to create a new wave of resentment among his supporters.

As the general election approaches, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown will have their work cut out to manage their political rivalry. Both leaders are skilled at manipulating public opinion and keeping their supporters happy, but this time they're facing a battle that could last until the election itself.
phi:2.7b: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown are trying to avoid their rivalry from overshadowing the upcoming election by insisting they will prioritize winning for Britain's best interests. However, many fear it is too late to repair any damage as the genie of their rivalry continues to cause division among senior cabinet colleagues, backbenchers, and political parties. The rift has even prompted rumors that Mr. Blair should restore Mr. Brown as the central figure in election planning. Despite their attempts at unity, they have failed to put an end to speculation fueled by newspaper headlines and gossip from Westminster. Mr. Blair's comments about a new Labour manifesto and Mr. Brown's denial of reneging on a deal to hand him power last year have only served to stir up further speculation. The two men are accused of fueling the rumors by their own behavior, as they avoid simple denials of central claims and instead engage in public disputes. This gossip has been sustained by "friends" of the two men, with whispers and private briefings adding fuel to the fire. Downing Street believes Mr. Brown is acting out of petty spite and that he poses a threat to the smooth running of government due to his sulk. While the public may be uninterested or concerned about the internal drama, political experts agree that if this continues into the election, it could seriously damage the Labour party. Despite their awareness of the danger, Mr. Blair and Mr. Brown have not been successful in putting a lid on speculation, leaving them with only four months to the next election.
orca-mini:3b: Rivalry between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown is causing concern among Labour MPs, who fear that it could hurt their chances in the upcoming general election. The two leaders are reportedly struggling to unite behind a common manifesto and have been accused of making matters worse by feeding speculation with their own behavior. Some backbenchers worry that voters are either uninterested or afraid of the chaos within the Labour party. The prime minister has scheduled a monthly press conference to clash with a keynote speech by the chancellor, while Brown has set out what is seen as a rival manifesto and appears to be embarking on his own personal campaign. Some MPs believe that the two men need to focus on governing effectively for the good of the country rather than engaging in a media-only obsession.
hermes3:3b: Rivalry between Blair and Brown threatens UK election.

However, some in Westminster believe the rift is too deep to repair by the time of the election. Both Blair and Brown have been accused of fueling speculation with their own comments and behavior, potentially damaging their party's image during the campaign.

Despite both insisting on their shared goal of winning the next election and governing in Britain's best interests, their actions and public statements have fueled speculation about a deep-seated rift. This rift concerns many Labour MPs with slim majorities, who fear it may jeopardize their re-election prospects.

High-ranking officials like Ian Gibson, John Reid, and Lord Haskins have warned of the electoral risks associated with the ongoing dispute.
